qas.question: Who decides who gets to speak in the chamber debates?
What is also decided by the Presiding Officer?

answers.text: amount of time for which they are allowed to speak
amount of time for which they are allowed to speak
the amount of time for which they are allowed to speak

qas.question: What does the Presiding Officer try to achieve a balance of between speakers?

answers.text: a balance between different viewpoints and political parties

qas.question: What language other than English has the Scottish Parliament had meetings in?

answers.text: Scots, Gaelic, or any other language with the agreement of the Presiding Officer

qas.question: The Presiding Officer tries the achieve a balance between similar viewpoints and whom?
Closing speakers are given between 5 and how many minutes?
Succeeding speakers are usually allotted more what?

plausible_answers.text: large number of members wish to participate in the debate

qas.question: The Presiding Officer can increase speaking time if what?

context: <a0_0><a0_2>The <a0_1>Presiding Officer<a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> (or Deputy Presiding Officer) decides who speaks in chamber debates and <a1_2>the <a1_0><a1_1>amount of time for which they are allowed to speak<a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>. Normally, the Presiding Officer tries to achieve <a2_2>a balance between <a2_0><a2_1>different viewpoints<a2_0/> and <b5_0>political parties<b5_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/> when selecting members to speak. Typically, <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><b6_0>ministers or party leaders<b6_0/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/> open debates, with opening speakers given between 5 and <b7_0>20<b7_0/> minutes, and succeeding speakers allocated less <b8_0>time<b8_0/>. The Presiding Officer can reduce speaking time if a <b9_0>large number of members wish to participate in the debate<b9_0/>. Debate is more informal than in some parliamentary systems. Members may call each other directly by name, rather than by constituency or cabinet position, and hand clapping is allowed. Speeches to the chamber are normally delivered in English, but members may use <a4_2>Scots, Gaelic, or any other language with the agreement of the Presiding Officer<a4_2/>. The Scottish Parliament has conducted debates in the <a4_0><a4_1>Gaelic<a4_1/><a4_0/> language.
